notes:
1. Density ($\rho$)

Density is the mass of a substance per unit volume. It is a measure of how tightly packed the matter is.

$$ \rho = \frac{m}{V} $$
  • Units: kg/m³ (SI) or lb/ft³ (US Customary).
  • The density of water at 4°C is approximately 1000 kg/m³ or 62.4 lb/ft³.

2. Specific Volume (v)

Specific volume is the reciprocal of density. It is the volume occupied by a unit mass of a substance.

$$ v = \frac{V}{m} = \frac{1}{\rho} $$
  • Units: m³/kg (SI).

3. Specific Weight ($\gamma$)

Specific weight is the weight of a substance per unit volume.

$$ \gamma = \frac{W}{V} = \frac{mg}{V} = \rho g $$
  • Units: N/m³ (SI).
  • $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity.

4. Specific Gravity (SG)

Specific gravity is the ratio of the density of a substance to the density of a reference substance, usually water at 4°C. It is a dimensionless quantity.

$$ SG = \frac{\rho_{substance}}{\rho_{water}} = \frac{\gamma_{substance}}{\gamma_{water}} $$

If $SG > 1$, the substance is denser than water and will sink. If $SG < 1$, it is less dense and will float.

solvedExamples.question: An object has a mass of 500 kg and a volume of 0.2 m³. What is its density?
solvedExamples.explanation: Density is mass divided by volume: $\rho = \frac{m}{V} = \frac{500 \text{ kg}}{0.2 \text{ m³}} = 2500$ kg/m³.

solvedExamples.question: The specific gravity of mercury is 13.6. What is its density? (Density of water = 1000 kg/m³).
solvedExamples.explanation: Specific gravity is the ratio of the substance's density to water's density: $SG = \rho / \rho_{water}$. Rearranging gives $\rho = SG \cdot \rho_{water} = 13.6 \cdot 1000 \text{ kg/m³} = 13600$ kg/m³.

solvedExamples.question: What is the specific weight of a fluid with a density of 800 kg/m³? (Use g = 9.81 m/s²).
solvedExamples.explanation: Specific weight is density times the acceleration of gravity: $\gamma = \rho g = (800 \text{ kg/m³})(9.81 \text{ m/s²}) = 7848$ N/m³.
